sn8.1:4.2: At one time Venerable Vaṅgīsa was staying near Āḷavī, at the Aggāḷava Tree-shrine, together with his mentor, Venerable Nigrodhakappa.
sn8.1:4.3: Now at that time Vaṅgīsa was junior, recently gone forth. He had been left behind to look after the dwelling.
sn8.1:4.4: Then several women dressed in all their finery went to the monastery at Aggāḷava in order to inspect the dwelling.
sn8.1:4.5: When Vaṅgīsa saw them he became dissatisfied, with lust infecting his mind.
sn8.1:4.9: that I’ve become dissatisfied, with lust infecting my mind. How can I expect someone else to dispel my dissatisfaction and give rise to satisfaction?
sn8.1:4.10: Why don’t I do it myself?”
sn8.1:4.11: Then, on the occasion of dispelling his own dissatisfaction and giving rise to satisfaction, he recited these verses:
sn8.1:5.4: by the reckless thoughts of the Dark One.
sn8.1:6.1: Even if a thousand mighty princes and great archers,
sn8.1:7.4: for I stand firm in the teaching.
sn8.1:8.1: I heard this with my own ears
sn8.1:8.2: from the Buddha, Kinsman of the Sun,
sn8.1:8.3: about the path going to extinguishment;
sn8.1:9.1: Wicked One, if you come near me
sn8.1:9.3: I’ll act in such a way that you, Death,
sn8.1:9.4: won’t even see the path I travel.”
